snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
"With less people affected and dying than from the yearly seasonal flu, this "virus" is being hyped way out of proportion on purpose as they are now testing out quarantining entire huge cities like Shanghai and Wuhan, and the sheeple seem to be following suit as expected. This is being used as a vehicle to push/test draconian government measures that would never be rolled out otherwise.
They are now also developing a vaccine which will likely be forced on people one way or another. 

Here in Thailand 90% of people are wearing face-masks, there are temperature checks to get into department stores, tumbleweeds blowing through airports, and the most disturbing to me is the biggest bank in Thailand just closed all foreign exchange branches urging the public to stop using paper money claiming it is helping spread the virus and is pushing for everyone to use cashless currencies. This CV is serving better than fake alien invasion as far as rolling out the NWO plan. Successfully quarantining entire huge cities with dozens of millions of people like Shanghai and Wuhan without a hitch is scary. And the scariest thing is how sheepishly the people believe everything their lying governments and medias tell them."  - Eric Dubay

snippet.textDisplay:
Moving people around isn't the end result either. You are infected, then you become infectious, then you get symptoms, then you still have some symptoms but you are no longer infectious, finally you are healthy or dead.

Those that are infected are less likely to infect others IF they know they are infected. They will be in a hospital hopefully in isolation.
Those that have been infected but stopped being infectious can travel with impunity. They can't be infected again and they won't infect others unless they carry the infection outside their bodies.
This is why spread halts so suddenly, those infected all had enough time to become healthy before encountering another non-infected person. The chances of this happening increase with the percentage of the population that has gotten infected.

Personally i don't really know what's worse, becoming infected NOW when everybody knows what it is and are ready to deal with it. Ofc assuming there's still available resources.
Or becoming infected much later in a "second wave" when most of the preparations have been dismantled and everything is back to normal.

Also, the global death rate for Corona is said to be between 2% and 3.4% depending on which source you ask. I am sure a lot of cases go unreported as well.
That's not a huge risk if you ask me. People still play the lottery hoping to win the big price and extremely few do win.
I am not really scared of being one of 40 people who would die to the disease.
Add to that, i am in the "no risk" zone as far as my age goes. That is, the prognosis is that 0.2% of those around my age will actually die from it. Double the risk of dying from the flu. Or one out of 500 people. Everyone else who's been infected will outlive the disease.

The coronavirus spreads like any other flu by the way. The only reason it's gotten so much attention is because it's basically twice as deadly as the flu. Which isn't a lot really.

snippet.textDisplay: And if we do a great job and our response to closing things down and limiting spread are effective... we're guaranteed that a large portion of the public will interpret that as proof that it was never worth worrying about and feel tricked, damaging faith in the public health infrastructure.  They'll end up seeing it how people think of the Y2K problem now.  Because we had adequate preparation and minimized the damage caused, they conclude there never was a problem at all.  These sorts of large social-scale problems worry me.
snippet.textOriginal: And if we do a great job and our response to closing things down and limiting spread are effective... we're guaranteed that a large portion of the public will interpret that as proof that it was never worth worrying about and feel tricked, damaging faith in the public health infrastructure.  They'll end up seeing it how people think of the Y2K problem now.  Because we had adequate preparation and minimized the damage caused, they conclude there never was a problem at all.  These sorts of large social-scale problems worry me.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have seen posts on both Reddit and Facebook calling this a conspiracy/fake news. To be sure 3000 cases in the U.S. (March 15) is 1 per 100,000 people. At this level people can convince themselves that they don't know anyone who has it, no big deal.

At present the worldometer site shows it slowing down, with a current doubling time of a about a week. This is NOT true in the U.S. where TRUe leadership is making itself felt.

But I anticipate the following:

* People respond well to the 'call to arms'. Then nothing much happens. They don't know anyone who's sick (We have 39 cases in Alberta for 4.3 million people -- slightly lower than the U.S. Mind you, given the testing envrionment in the U.S. I suspect their numbers are understated.)


* People relax, and go back to work, school, resume their old habits.


* E p resumes it's value of 1.2

* New alarm goes off.


Lather, rinse, repeat.


Anyway. Can I suggest that you update this video every couple of weeks as you can?


What is the effect of Ep being periodic on a reverse sawtooth function. E.g. 1.25 PANIC 1.05 1.07 1.09 1.11 1.13.... 1.25 PANIC?

At present the worldometer site shows it slowing down, with a current doubling time of a about a week.  This is NOT true in the U.S. where TRUe leadership is making itself felt.

But I anticipate the following:

* People respond well to the 'call to arms'.  Then nothing much happens.  They don't know anyone who's sick (We have 39 cases in Alberta for 4.3 million people -- slightly lower than the U.S.  Mind you, given the testing envrionment in the U.S. I suspect their numbers are understated.)


* People relax, and go back to work, school, resume their old habits.

* New alarm goes off.


Lather, rinse, repeat.


Anyway.  Can I suggest that you update this video every couple of weeks as you can?

snippet.textDisplay:
FWIW, the 7th root of US Growth Factor for the past 7 days is 1.27375. (a pretty decent past-week rolling average value)

That puts us on target for ~ May 1 inflection point and burn out by May 20.

The world minus China has a 1.1456 7th root of past 7 day growth factor.

snippet.textDisplay:
Logistical, but great vid. Clarity is a good thing.

The worry thing, however, I worry about. Sometimes too much worry combined with too little clarity leads to stupidity, which can be worse than clarity without worry. What we want is for people to follow a few simple guidelines. Transmitting the guidelines with fear to generate worry creates stupidity like hoarding, profiteering, defiance, and any number of other turd-chucking behaviors that, while natural to primates of the current state of evolution, are distinctly suboptimal for addressing novel viruses.

More clarity and due concern will help. Fear and worry do not add much to mitigation. The dividing lines here are murky sometimes, but important to consider.
snippet.textOriginal:
Logistical, but great vid. Clarity is a good thing.

Transmitting the guidelines with fear to generate worry creates stupidity like hoarding, profiteering, defiance, and any number of other turd-chucking behaviors that, while natural to primates of the current state of evolution, are distinctly suboptimal for addressing novel viruses.

More clarity and due concern will help. Fear and worry do not add much to mitigation. The dividing lines here are murky sometimes, but important to consider.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think u are missing a key parameter in Virus infections and this mathematical model: The Virus itself mutates to be able to become more acceptable to the host (now human...till now it was bats). The virus in the body of the carrier becomes more and more benign as it fights with the immunity of the human beings and adjusts its mutation accordingly (to make itself more acceptable to the host, so it can survive). This phenomenon is happening rt now as we discuss and across millions of human hosts. The Mutation rates of viruses are in seconds (see https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK209710/ (How infection works).) and the rate at which they can adjust to become more docile are fast. So really it is evolution on steroids. I wrote an article on this on LinkedIn:
https://lnkd.in/gxqUdyv

snippet.textDisplay: The math is good and well explained - but for it to make more sense, the problem is really the inconsistent data quality. Many countries changes how often they test for virus during the outbreak. It often means, they will conduct less tests as the outbreak rises. It doesn't mean they have less cases to worry about. Maybe numbers should probably be only taking the serious cases into account. It's not critics of a well explained video, just something people should consider if they do their own studies.
